abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Structural Reform
            Support Project for Georgia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in projects
            which involve public sector reform activities, such as
            hospital restructuring, the importance of effective and far
            reaching public information campaigns cannot be
            underestimated. This is particularly critical before the
            start of reform activities, in order to promote buy-in and
            ownership of change activities. In this process, although
            specific and targeted focus can rest on the stakeholders who
            will be most affected by the change, an effort can also be
            made to obtain buy-in from champions in key stakeholder
            groups. Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) is essential in
            order to track indicators and assess their performance. In
            so doing, it will be possible to make necessary changes,
            such as re-define indicator-targets in line with reality on
            the ground, or modify indicators so that they are closely
            linked with activities. In order for this process to take
            place effectively, however, outcome and output indicators
            must be tightly constructed and linked with both baseline
            and target data. In addition, it is also very important that
            due cognizance is taken of the information system that
            underlies the M&E framework. Finally, supervision
            missions must take their responsibility to monitor and
            report back on progress toward attaining agreed indicators
            during the life of a project very seriously.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Reform Support Project
            aims to accelerate the change in the respective functions of
            the public and private sectors in delivering key services in
            Georgia. The program provides support to the key reform
            measures included in the Third Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAC 3) (report number P7316) and Energy Sector Adjustment
            Credit (ESAC). The project has four main components. The
            first component supports the establishment of a revolving
            hospital restructuring fund, whereby the proceeds from the
            sale of excess hospitals will be reinvested in the public
            sector health system. The second component addresses private
            sector development and the financial sector: it supports the
            open, competitive, and strategic privatization of a few
            large infrastructure enterprises by financing financial,
            legal, and technical advisory services; strengthens the
            capacity of the energy and infrastructure regulatory
            institutions to enable strong private sector participation;
            and strengthens the supervision department and monetary
            policy capacity of the national bank. The third component
            strengthens budget management, builds the institutional
            capacity of the finance ministry, improves the license
            regime, and supports the program of public information and
            public relations on economic reforms. The fourth component
            helps establish a credible and affordable safety net which
            includes pension reform as well as targeted assistance to
            the poor.
